Introduction

Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is characterized by the presence of 3 copies of chromosome 13.  It is the most severe and least common (ie, 1 in 7,000 live births) of the trisomy disorders (eg, 21, 18, 13).  It is associated with severe congenital anomalies and a high mortality rate.

Pathogenesis



Normally, homologous chromosomes separate during meiosis, resulting in 4 gametes with 1 copy of each chromosome in each gamete.  However, in meiotic nondisjunction, a pair of homologous chromosomes fails to separate, resulting in 4 gametes with 0, 1, or 2 copies of the chromosome in each gamete (

figure 1
).  If a gamete with 2 copies of the chromosome is fertilized by a gamete with 1 copy of the chromosome, then the zygote has 3 copies of the chromosome.  Maternal meiotic nondisjunction is a sporadic event that occurs during oogenesis and is the most common cause of trisomy 13.



Less commonly, trisomy 13 occurs due to a robertsonian translocation or mosaicism.



  • Robertsonian translocation:  Occurs when the long arm of a chromosome is translocated to a different chromosome, forming a single chromosome with genetic material from both chromosomes (
    figure 2
    ).  In trisomy 13, robertsonian translocations most commonly occur when the long arm of chromosome 13 translocates to chromosome 14, forming chromosome 13q14q.  In this case, the fertilized zygote has 46 chromosomes; however, there is a third copy of the long arm of chromosome 13 (eg, 46,XX,âˆ’14, +13q14q), resulting in the trisomy 13 phenotype.
  • Mosaicism:  Occurs due to mitotic (not meiotic) nondisjunction in early embryonic development, resulting in a fetus who has both normal (ie, 46,XX) and abnormal (ie, 47,XX,+13) cell lines and the trisomy 13 phenotype.  Because mosaic trisomy 13 occurs due to postzygotic mitotic nondisjunction, it is not inherited.


Therefore, risk factors for trisomy 13 include:



  • Advanced maternal age:  The risk for de novo (ie, no family history) trisomy 13 increases with increasing maternal age (>35) due to the increased risk for meiotic errors (eg, nondisjunction) during oogenesis.
  • Family history of trisomy 13 caused by a robertsonian translocation (including prior pregnancy):  Either parent may be a carrier for a translocation involving trisomy 13 (eg, 13q14q).


The phenotypic features of trisomy 13 reflect a defect in the fusion of the prechordal mesoderm, an integral embryologic structure affecting the growth of the midface, eyes, and forebrain.  This results in catastrophic midline defects.

Diagnosis



Trisomy 13 can be diagnosed prenatally or postnatally.

Prenatal testing



Prenatal testing involves first-trimester (ie, 10-13 weeks gestation) screening tests (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
), followed by diagnostic tests with a fetal karyotype via chorionic villus sampling (
figure 3
) or amniocentesis (
figure 4
).  Available first-trimester screening tests include:



  • Cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA):  Noninvasive screening test that assesses fetal DNA in the maternal circulation for aneuploidies.  cffDNA should be assessed at â‰¥10 weeks gestation, when the fetal fraction (amount of fetal DNA in the maternal circulation) is adequate to yield accurate results.  Although cffDNA testing is highly sensitive (>96%), diagnostic testing is required for all positive screening tests.
  • Combined test:  Measures maternal serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) and hCG combined with ultrasonography.  The combination of low PAPP-A, low hCG, and enlarged nuchal translucency (hypoechoic region between soft tissue layers along the posterior cervical spine) on sonogram is suggestive of trisomy 13 and requires confirmation with diagnostic testing.

Postnatal testing



Trisomy 13 is most often diagnosed prenatally; however, in cases of suspected trisomy 13 after birth (eg, newborn with characteristic dysmorphic features), the diagnosis should be confirmed with a full karyotype (

image 1
).  Other types of genetic testing can be suggestive of trisomy 13 (eg, fluorescence in situ hybridization) (
image 2
), but a full karyotype is required to detect cases of trisomy 13 due to robertsonian translocations and mosaicism.

Clinical presentation



The triad of microphthalmia/anophthalmia, cleft lip/palate, and postaxial polydactyly is characteristic of trisomy 13, but the clinical presentation varies and involves multiple organ systems (

figure 5
).

General appearance



Dysmorphic features of the head and neck include microcephaly with sloping forehead, cutis aplasia, microphthalmia/anophthalmia, hypertelorism/hypotelorism, upslanting palpebral fissures, midline facial defects (eg, cyclopia, proboscis, cleft lip/palate) (

figure 6
), micrognathia, and an absent philtrum.  Polydactyly of the hands and feet can occur, and some patients have prominent heels (ie, rocker-bottom feet).

Neurologic



Neurologic defects include holoprosencephaly (ie, incomplete division of the forebrain into the right and left hemispheres, resulting in a single lateral ventricle), partial olfactory and optic nerve development, severe intellectual disability, seizures, central apnea (due to brainstem abnormalities), and deafness.

Cardiovascular



Cardiovascular defects include ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, and dextroposition.

Miscellaneous



Less common defects involve the gastrointestinal (eg, omphalocele, umbilical hernia), genitourinary (eg, cryptorchidism, bicornuate uterus), and renal (eg, polycystic kidneys, hydronephrosis) systems.  Many of these congenital anomalies can be detected on prenatal ultrasonography.

Management and prognosis



Because of the severity of the congenital anomalies, the majority of affected fetuses die in utero.  The median survival rate for live births is 7 days, and 80% of patients die within the first month of life.  Therefore, due to the high mortality rate, management is generally supportive, although the approach to management varies depending on the severity of the congenital anomalies and the family's beliefs and values.  A multidisciplinary approach to medical or surgical interventions should be taken, with an emphasis on palliative care.  Rarely, patients survive beyond early infancy, often with severe intellectual disability.

Summary



Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is characterized by the presence of 3 copies of chromosome 13.  It is the most severe and least common (ie, 1 in 7,000 live births) of the trisomy disorders (eg, 21, 18, 13).  It is associated with severe congenital anomalies (eg, holoprosencephaly, midline facial defects) and a high mortality rate.  Most cases are diagnosed prenatally, and affected fetuses often die in utero.  Management is generally supportive, with a compassionate, multidisciplinary approach.
